p: Migration is a naturally plastic trait. Observed changes in migratory behaviour include short-stopping [ 50] and changes in overwintering locations [ 51]. For passerines, however, these observations are mostly restricted to short-distance migrants, which already demonstrate a wide range of migratory movements [ 50]. Long-distance migrants, which tend to have a smaller diversity of migratory movements, may have lower adaptive capacity, rendering them less resilient to environmental change than resident and short-distance migrants [ 9]. Our models do not currently account for plasticity, but if we are to better understand how migratory species may respond to environmental change, this could be a key area for development.
